posts.name: mbhoxsie
Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
This was recently discussed in our FRC team’s Discord server.

One practical method involves measuring x/y/rotation signals from the camera, plotting them in AdvantageScope (and similar tools), and calculating the standard deviation of the noise in the signal.

Start with a stationary setup, assuming the mean error is zero, and deviations are noise. Test at various distances and angles to observe how the standard deviation changes with these factors. Choose an approach based on current field conditions—whether averaging, taking the worst case, or dynamically adjusting.

For higher accuracy, incorporate another reliable sensor to obtain a ground truth measurement. Follow the same noise analysis process to understand how standard deviation varies with distance/angle to the target.

Alternatively, continuously adjust until pose convergence feels stable. Smaller standard deviation indicates faster convergence; ensure measurements are sufficiently filtered before tuning.

Choose your preferred approach, mindful of ethical concerns regarding vibing your car, especially if it costs \$50k.

link_counts.title: Question regarding standard deviations in vision measurements

posts.name: khope
posts.cooked:
Up to you how to proceed. No shame in using vibes when building a FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) car, though I might shame you if you use vibes while designing the car I paid $50k for.

Warning: Possibly a dumb question: What is vibes?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
As far as I know, it refers to using feelings and intuition to make technical decisions even without much data available. This approach can be problematic, particularly if the decisions have significant consequences or if the decision-makers lack sufficient time to reflect on their emotions before acting.

I’m no longer a teenager, though I try to use their language to communicate—hoping it works, albeit only partially.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
We used a heuristic-backed system to dynamically adjust standard deviations for each post-estimate. We did not use the method setVisionMeasurementStdDevs() because it meant that we had to provide one trust in vision for all estimates. However, not all estimates are equal in quality, and we wanted our code to reflect this. Instead, assuming we're talking CTRE, you can simply pass in a matrix along with the estimate each time you supply a pose estimate. This lets you pick and choose which estimates are more trustworthy. 

We implemented an algorithm to determine a standard deviation multiplier for scaling a default value around 10cm. Each factor influencing the multiplier gets its own unique weight and shift to fine-tune the vision system just right. After an hour of adjusting numbers, our pose estimates were stable and highly accurate.

Each factor influences the multiplier uniquely: closer tags are more reliable, ambiguous poses are less trustworthy, nearby estimates are discounted due to high latency, and seeing multiple tags makes an estimate more viable. We balanced these factors with specific weights and shifts to optimize our vision system effectively.

link_counts.title: Best tutorial on using photonvision with swerve drive to drive to apriltags

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
our pose estimates were both stable and highly accurate  
adjust timestamps for latency compensation  
does your latency adjustment vary with the robot velocity

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
Velocity compensation is a feature I've been interested in addressing but haven't yet tackled. Currently, it's not really an issue because we slow down as we score, making the differences negligible. Additionally, we use low-resolution cameras (240x320) resulting in numerous pose estimates. By the time older estimates become unreliable—after about 200 frames (from four cameras operating at 100fps for half a second)—new estimates are already accurate enough.

We don't currently prioritize fixing this issue. However, it's not a particularly critical concern. Still, I'd like to respond thoughtfully to your inquiry. To address it, I propose adjusting the difference multiplier based on velocity. This approach would instruct the system to trust subsequent poses more when moving quickly. While this wouldn't fundamentally alter anything, determining the appropriate scaling factor would require time. Once that's established, I plan to refine the behavior further, enhancing trust for poses aligned with the robot's motion and reducing trust for those moving oppositely. This evolution remains in the conceptual stage.
